clinicalDescription: Overview: inflammation of blood vessels restricting blood flow which results in organ and tissue damage, acute or chronic. Also known as angiitis and arteritis. Various types of vasculitis (Behcet's disease, Behcet's disease, etc)Presentation: Symptoms vary greatly depending on the type. Include, fever, headache, fatigue, wgt loss, general aches and pains, night sweats, rash, numbness or weaknessAssessment: C-reactive protein, CBC, anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies test, urinalysis, xrays, ultrasound, CT, MRI, PET, angiography, biopsy (affected area)Plan: Control the inflammation and resolve underlying disease triggering the vasculitis. Corticosteroids, steroid-sparing meds, depending on type - biologics, somtimes surgery if vasculitis caused an aneurysm or blocked arteries Prognosis: Depends on type of vasculitis and organs involved and how serious. Some initial success with treatment, some have flare-ups, and some vasculitis does not go away and requires ongoing treatment.
